The Order of Operations is morally wrong because it's supposedly a rote, mechanical method that hides the beauty of mathematics by locking the students into one rigid method . . . . but FOIL is beautiful?
PEMDAS works. I know it didn't work in the MinutePhysics video about it, but you had to break it pretty blatantly to force it to fail, making up new rules about always multiplying before division and always adding before subtraction (rules that do not exist in the Order of Operations.)

FOIL, on the other hand, is a fine, handy mnemonic--for students who know that it will stop working the moment they deal with trinomials or larger. But it doesn't show or explain the why or the reason it works any better than PEMDAS does . . . so why be fer the one and agin' t'other? Don't make no sense.

In another video, you criticized PEMDAS as a mnemonic for treating humans as robots. That's what FOIL does, too. It teaches kids a way to pass the test but it doesn't teach them anything about math. Why does Outside have to come before Inside but after First?

A much better approach to this is to teach double distribution. ( a + b)(c +d), by the distributive property, must be equal to
a(c+d) + b(c+d)

Distribute again to get ac + ad + bc + bd.

Distribution is a provable mathematical property. FOIL is not. Teach math, not mnemonics.  


Your physical illustration, however is excellent. If you think about it, it's a demonstration of double distribution, not FOIL. That's why some commenters here - who surely learned FOIL - are now saying "wow this really helped my intuition". You showed them that what's behind FOIL, which makes no intuitive sense, is actually a beautiful mathematical principle that is easy enough to grasp so that kids can handle it and don't need to be taught to be FOIL robots.

After the kid masters distribution, then maybe a mnemonic is useful as a shortcut. Don't take the shortcut first.

There's a free on-line book called "Nix the Tricks" that should be at least skimmed by anyone interested in teaching kids how to do math instead of how to pass tests.

For the people out there that dont understand, this video is a geometric proof of the distributive property. Henry set the problem into a rectangle with side lengths (a+b) and (c+d). If you want to find the area of the rectangle you have to multiply the rectangle's side lengths together. Henry did this by breaking up the rectangle into smaller ones with side lengths in respect to the segments of the larger rectangle's side lengths; for example  one rectangle with side (a) and (c) is a rectangle made from the segments of the larger rectangle's sides (a+b) and (c+d). He divided the rectangle for each segment into smaller rectangles whose areas are equal to the product of the side lengths; for example (a×c). The total area is the sum of the products of the side lengths of each rectangle; (a×c)+(a×d)+(b×c)+(b×d).

For those of you who don't see the application of math as "useful," you must remember that it is an integral part of everyday life. Physics and statistics and calculus and all other branches of math/science are all dependent on the ability to perform basic mathematical operations like this. If not for math and the way we apply it, life as we know it today and our hopes for the future would never be able to exist.

By stability axiom, we have (a+b) is a real number as long as a and b are, so let's call it N=(a+b). We know, by distributive axiom, what N(c+d)=Nc+Nd; so we have Nc+Nd=(a+b)c+(a+b)d. Applying again the distributive axiom, (a+b)c+(a+b)d=ac+bc+ad+bd. QED

a rectangle of sides "u" and "v" are changing over a time "t", as a a result the rectangles area is changing too. if we can use the derivative to find out the rate that "u" changes: du/dt and likewise for "v": dv/dt, then we can use the product rule to find out how the area changes: dA=u*(dv/dt)+v*(du/dt)+(du/dt)*(dv/dt) the last piece being too small to care about, since that's fundamentally what a derivative implies. The reverse should help with integration by parts as well.

But this *does* illustrate the process!

It's a geometric proof for FOIL. The multiplication problem is turned into a rectangle, where the factors become the length and the width and the product becomes the area (because for a rectangle, area = length * width). Then he cuts the rectangle up, showing that it splits into four smaller rectangles: one whose area is the product of the "firsts," one whose area is the product of the "seconds," and so on for the "inners" and "lasts." It's analogous to how FOIL works and is easy to visualize.

Honestly, I think the video went over YOUR head. He's using a geometric analogy (where area represents quantity) in order to provide an illustration of why FOIL works. While it may be simple, it's also extremely clever and not something commonly seen in math classes or textbooks.

I disliked this video because, to me, it shows the most complicated way of multiplying two sums. It works for sums of 2 numbers, but what if you have more? Isn't it much easier to do it like this:
(a + b + c) * (x + y + z) = x*(a + b + c) + y*(a + b + c) + z*(a + b + c) =
= xa + xb + xc + ya + yb + yc + za + zb + zc

You don't have to be of a certain intelligence, but certain base knowledge should be assumed, and extremely basic mathematics is not appropriate. If you want to know extremely basic maths, there are plenty of online resources for kids. Minute Physics however has always been about making more complex areas of physics accessible to people who don't go on to further education in that area. It's perfectly fair to want this to be maintained.
I'm guessing you were joking, taking the piss out of the simplicity of the video?

Its target audience is not your age group but for everyone, so such fundamentally basic maths isn't appropriate. Nobody's claiming to be complex; anyone above the age of, say, 14, will know this. Given the usually more complex nature of this channel, it is therefore understandable for people to be disappointed and to voice this.

Second, by the rules of polynomials, the equation  x² + -1x - 20 IS simplified.. (x+4)(x-5) is a polynomial... but technically it is not written correctly because in polynomials you need to GROUP SIMILAR items together. This is why  x² + -1x - 20 is a simplified polynomial: you have  x², x to the first power (which is just x), and 20 (another number that isn't x). In the original equation (x + 4)(x - 5), x and other numbers are NOT grouped together.
First of all, a quadratic equation is usually written in the form ax² + bx + c. (x+4)(x-5) is not written this way, but  x² + -1x + -20 is. This makes it easier to graph. (continued in next comment)

Sorry if I further insult the collective intelligence of the minutephysics community, but i think a good chunk of the people disliking are missing the point of this video.
At first glance, it seems like all Henry is doing is showing how to foil a product, but that is not the case.
(a+b)*(c+d) represents a rectangle of width a+b and height c+d. This large rectangle can be constructed as the sum of 4 smaller ones (a*c a*d b*c b*d) this is what he was trying to show with the foil cut into 4 pieces

I don't know why I didn't think of it, but my calculus instructor's method only works if the parenthesis bit is being squared! For example, you can use his method on problems such as (a+b)^2, (9x+4)^2, and (3x+y)^2, BUT not in cases where it's too different parenthesis bits such as (a+b)(c+d), (9x+4)(2x+6), and (3x+y)(x+4y). In my calculus courses, we just encountered more problems like (a+b)^2 than we did problems like (a+b)(c+d). Sorry if this cause any confusion!
If you're learning this in Algebra II, you needed him to be your Algebra I teacher.
love these videos!
Why are you guys disliking this video? There's nothing wrong with it. It's a proof of concept and it teaches those who have never learnt it before.

Yeah, you can't use his method in cases where the parenthesis bit isn't being squared, but In my Calculus courses, we encountered more problems like (a+b)^2 than we did (a+b)(c+d) which I think is the only reason he brought it up.

I will certainly do my best! Suppose you are given the problem (a+b)^2. Using the FOIL method, we would end up with a^2+ab+ab+b^2 which would simplify to a^2+2ab+b^2. What my calculus instructor is saying is square the a (=a^2), double the product of a and b (=2ab), and square the b (=b^2). You would add all of these to get the answer a^2+2ab+b^2. His method just skips the adding of ab+ab. An example with numbers (not that you would normally use FOIL): (2+3)^2 = 2^2+2(2*3)+3^2 = 4+12+9=25.

The rectangle's top edge had length a+b, the side had length c+d. Hence the whole area of the foil is (a+b)*(c+d).
He divided the rectangle into four rectangles who's total area is, obviously, the same as the original. These sub-rectangles have area a*c, b*c, a*d and b*d as shown.
Since the areas are the same: (a+b) * (c+d) = a*c + b*c + a*d + b*d

A neat proof for fans of geometry I guess, but could have been made clearer/ been complicated enough to warrant explanation.
